Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Integrating Nanotechnology with Cell Biology and Neuroscience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This IGERT award supports a broadly-based education and training program at the University of New Mexico that will enable students from various disciplines to develop new nanoscale imaging and sensing tools and to apply them in investigations of fundamental problems in cell biology and neuroscience. By infusing training in cell biology and neuroscience with training in the technological basis of chemistry, electrical engineering, and physics, the university will create an exciting learning environment in which to prepare students for the challenges and opportunities presented by the nanotechnology revolution. The program will include internships at national laboratories and industry, travel to national and international meetings, international collaboration combined with internship placements, and a web-based dissemination. The research component of the program will generate improved understanding of important and relatively unexplored biological processes, enabled by creation of new imaging and sensing instruments. To realize this goal, the program will capitalize on the existing strengths to develop new quantum-dot-based technologies coupled with hyperspectral and multiphoton microscopy that carry the potential to revolutionize research on genomic, cellular, and synaptic activities. The educational component of the program will emphasize collaboration across traditional academic disciplines, with co-advisors from cell biology/neuroscience and engineering/science fields, rotations between various laboratories with different research styles, and active interactions among students with different academic backgrounds. New courses developed under this project will lead to a Graduate Certificate Program in Biomedical Science and Engineering with Concentration in Nanotechnology, to be followed by a new PhD program in Systems Biology and Bioengineering. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching vision for the “Integrating Nanotechnology with Cell Biology and Neuroscience” (INCBN) IGERT program was to develop a new cadre of interdisciplinary scholars with excellent research skills, prepared for challenges of the 21st century brought by the nanotechnology revolution. The educational component of the INCBN program has emphasized collaboration across traditional academic disciplines, with co-advisors from cell biology/neuroscience and engineering/science fields, rotations between various laboratories with different research styles, and active interactions among students with different academic backgrounds. A new course on Colloidal Nanocrystals for Biomedical Applications has been developed under this program, and is now regularly offered as an interdisciplinary course, cross-listed between Electrical and Computer Engineering, Nanoscience and Microsystems, Biomedical Engineering, and Biomedical Sciences Graduate Program. The program has supported 35 Trainees, of which 17 were women, 3 were Hispanic, 1 was Native American, 1 was African American, and 1 was Pacific Islander. All Trainees attended weekly seminars, at which local and national experts were presenting their research. All Trainees also participated in the annual INCBN Symposium, aiming at broad popularization of the results of research conducted under the INCBN program. Five annual symposia have attracted 558 participants, with 57 invited speakers from 5 countries and 17 states, and 60 student posters. The international component of the program included 10-week long internships in Germany and Australia. The INCBN program website http://www.chtm.unm.edu/incbnigert/‎ has received over 14,000 hits.

The research component of the INCBN program has generated improved understanding of important and relatively unexplored biological processes, enabled by creation of new imaging and sensing instruments. To realize this goal, the participants have capitalized on the existing strengths to develop new quantum-dot-based technologies coupled with hyperspectral and multiphoton microscopy that carry the potential to revolutionize research on genomic, cellular, and synaptic activities. By infusing training in cell biology and neuroscience with the technological basis of chemistry, electrical engineering, and physics, the program has created an exciting learning environment in which to prepare students for the challenges and opportunities presented by the nanotechnology revolution. The INCBN program has resulted in 253 refereed publications, 27 book chapters, 6 books, 328 conference presentations, 45 patent applications, and 10 awarded patents.

The program has been described in detail in an invited paper “Interdisciplinary research and education – NSF IGERT program on Integrating Nanotechnology with Cell Biology and Neuroscience at the University of New Mexico”, published in the Journal of Materials Education vol. 32, issue #1-2, pp. 83-92, April 2010.
